package xmlservlet;

import javax.servlet.*;
import javax.servlet.http.*;

import java.io.*;
import org.w3c.dom.*;
import org.xml.sax.*;
import org.apache.xml.serialize.*;

public  class XmlServlet extends GenericServlet {
    protected Document makeChange(Document doc) {
                Element root   = doc.getDocumentElement();
                Element e      = doc.createElement("Fred");
                root.appendChild(e);
                return doc;
    }
    public XmlServlet() {}
    public void init(ServletConfig config) throws ServletException {
                System.out.println("Initializing XmlServlet");
    }

    public void service(ServletRequest req, ServletResponse res)
                throws ServletException {
        try {
            DocumentBuilderFactory factory =
                                DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance();
            DocumentBuilder builder = factory.newDocumentBuilder();
            int len = req.getContentLength();
            if (len <= 0) {
                res.setContentType("text/plain");
                ServletOutputStream out = res.getOutputStream();
                System.out.println("No Content");
                out.println("No Content");
            } else {
                byte[] b = new byte[len];
                req.getInputStream().read(b);
                // THIS IS WHERE THE ERROR MANIFESTS ITSELF
                // b has correct length but no data !!!!!!!!!!!!!
                ByteArrayInputStream bs = new ByteArrayInputStream(b);
                Document doc            = builder.parse(new InputSource(bs));
                Document changedDoc     = makeChange(doc);
                XMLSerializer ser =
                new XMLSerializer(
                     res.getOutputStream(),
                         new OutputFormat("xml",
                              "UTF-8", false));
                ser.serialize(changedDoc);
            }
        }
        catch (Throwable e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}

class XmlBridge {

    public XmlBridge() {}

    public Document sendRequest(URL url, Document doc) {
        Document changedDoc = doc;
    try {
        HttpURLConnection conn = (HttpURLConnection)url.openConnection();
        conn.setDoInput(true);
        conn.setDoOutput(true);
        conn.setRequestMethod("POST" );

            OutputStream out = conn.getOutputStream();
            // Specify the content type 
            XMLSerializer ser =
               new XMLSerializer(out, new OutputFormat("xml", "UTF-8", false));
            ser.serialize(doc);
        out.close();

            //get returned document
            DocumentBuilder builder = DocumentBuilderFactory.
                                      newInstance().newDocumentBuilder();
            changedDoc = builder.parse(new InputSource(conn.getInputStream()));
        }
    catch (Throwable e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }
    return changedDoc;
    }

      public static void main(String[] args) {
        try {  // Build up an XML Document
              DocumentBuilderFactory factory =
                                DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance();
              DocumentBuilder builder = factory.newDocumentBuilder();
              Document doc   = builder.newDocument();
              Element e      = doc.createElement("Order");
              e.appendChild(doc.createElement("Type"));
              e.appendChild(doc.createElement("Amount"));
              doc.appendChild(e);
            // Send it to the Servlet
              XmlBridge a = new XmlBridge();
              URL dest    = new URL
("http://localhost:8080/servlet/xmlservlet.XmlServlet");

              XMLSerializer ser   = new XMLSerializer(System.out,

("xml","UTF-8", false));
              ser.serialize(changedDoc);
              System.out.println("\nFinished");

text:
You're doing the upload with a form encoding content type, which is incorrect 
here (you're uploading text/xml, and not parameters). Since you are not calling 
getParameters, the problem would be that the adapter would apparentl parse them 
anyway (I don't know why yet), which may be incorrect (at least, it should be a 
lazy evaluation).
I'll check to see if there is a bug.

Also, your byte reading algorithm is bad (do a loop to do that, and handle 
negative values).
creator: remm@apache.org
morri70@ieee.org
text:
Absolutely right - stupidly I assumed XmlSerializer was setting the content 
type when obviously it can't.
However I thought getParameter().. OR getReader()/getInputStream() were choices 
that the servlet could make even if form urlencoded?

Yes, as I implied in my comment, I think there's a bug (if you don't call 
getParameters, it shouldn't parse the parameters).

You have a nice workaround in the meantime (set the right content-type, and it 
shouldn't parse the parameters).
creator: remm@apache.org

text:
I tested using a modified HelloWorldExample, with a doPost method and traces, 
using a request like:

POST /examples/servlet/HelloWorldExample HTTP/1.1
Host: localhost:8080
Content-length: 10
Content-type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

0123456789

I entered the query with a telnet. The HelloWorld servlet was able to correctly 
read the bytes sent, even with the incorrect content-type.
